										<p></p><div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="noprint" style="float:right; box-shadow: 0 0 4px #BDBDBD inset; background-color: #FFFFFF; border-radius: 5px; width:150px; padding:10px; margin-left: 10px; margin-bottom: 15px;">

</div>
<p>The <b>3 nanometer (<a href="/wiki/3_nm" class="mw-redirect" title="3 nm">3 nm</a> or 30 Å) lithography process</b> is a <a href="/wiki/technology_node" title="technology node">technology node</a> semiconductor manufacturing 
</p>
<dl><dd>process following the <a href="/wiki/5_nm_lithography_process" title="5 nm lithography process">5 nm process</a> node. </dd></dl>
<p>Commercial <a href="/wiki/integrated_circuit" title="integrated circuit">integrated circuit</a> manufacturing using 3 nm process is set to begin some time around <a href="/wiki/2023" title="2023">2023</a>.
</p><p>The term "<a href="/wiki/3_nm" class="mw-redirect" title="3 nm">3 nm</a>" is simply a commercial name for a generation of a certain size and its technology, and 
</p><span id="ezoic-pub-ad-placeholder-160" class="ezoic-adpicker-ad"></span>
<dl><dd><b>does not</b> represent any geometry of the transistor.</dd></dl>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Industry">Industry</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=3_nm_lithography_process&action=edit&section=1" title="Edit section: Industry">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2><span id="ezoic-pub-ad-placeholder-170" class="ezoic-adpicker-ad"></span><span data-ez-ph-id="170" style="margin-right:0px !important;margin-bottom:15px !important;margin-left:0px !important;display:block !important;padding:0;float:none !important;box-sizing:content-box;margin-top:15px !important;text-align:left !important;min-width:728px;min-height:400px;max-width:100% !important;line-height:0px;"></span>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Intel"><a href="/wiki/Intel" class="mw-redirect" title="Intel">Intel</a></span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=3_nm_lithography_process&action=edit&section=2" title="Edit section: Intel">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>P1278 Intel's 5-nanometer (renamed as Intel 20A) process node is expected to ramp around the 2H <a href="/wiki/2024" title="2024">2024</a>/<a href="/wiki/2025" title="2025">2025</a> timeframe. 
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="TSMC"><a href="/wiki/TSMC" class="mw-redirect" title="TSMC">TSMC</a></span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=3_nm_lithography_process&action=edit&section=3" title="Edit section: TSMC">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>N3 technology will offer up to 70% logic density gain, up to 15% speed improvement at the same power and up to 
</p>
<dl><dd>30% power reduction at the same speed as compared with N5 technology (According to TSMCs website). </dd></dl>
<p>If this holds true we could see 300+ MT/mm2. 
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Samsung"><a href="/wiki/Samsung" class="mw-redirect" title="Samsung">Samsung</a></span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=3_nm_lithography_process&action=edit&section=4" title="Edit section: Samsung">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>On May 24, <a href="/wiki/2017" title="2017">2017</a> Samsung announced they will be switching to a transistor they call <i>Multi-Bridge-Channel FET</i> 
</p>
<dl><dd>(<i>MBCFET</i>), an extension of a  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gate-all-around&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Gate-all-around (page does not exist)">Gate-all-around</a> (GAA) <a href="/w/index.php?title=FET&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="FET (page does not exist)">FET</a>. </dd></dl>
<p>This is planned for somewhere after the <a href="/wiki/5_nm" class="mw-redirect" title="5 nm">5 nm</a> node but the exact timeline or specification is currently unknown.
</p>
